criteria: Ability to rewrite rational expressions using inspection.
Ability to rewrite rational expressions using long division.
Ability to rewrite rational expressions in the form q(x) + r(x)/b(x).
Understanding of the relationship between the degrees of r(x) and b(x).
descriptions: Student demonstrates no understanding of rational expressions or how to rewrite them.
Student attempts to rewrite rational expressions using inspection but shows significant errors and misunderstandings.
Student can rewrite simple rational expressions using inspection, but struggles with more complex expressions or makes frequent errors.
Student can generally rewrite rational expressions using inspection with minor errors or omissions.
Student accurately rewrites rational expressions using inspection with only occasional minor errors.
Student consistently and accurately rewrites rational expressions using inspection, demonstrating a strong understanding of the underlying principles.
Student demonstrates no understanding of long division or its application to rational expressions.
Student attempts to use long division to rewrite rational expressions but shows significant errors and misunderstandings.
Student can perform long division on simple rational expressions, but struggles with more complex expressions or makes frequent errors.
Student can generally perform long division on rational expressions with minor errors or omissions.
Student accurately performs long division on rational expressions with only occasional minor errors.
Student consistently and accurately performs long division on rational expressions, demonstrating a strong understanding of the process.
Student does not demonstrate an understanding of how to rewrite rational expressions in the specified form.
Student attempts to rewrite rational expressions in the specified form but shows significant errors and misunderstandings.
Student can rewrite simple rational expressions in the specified form, but struggles with more complex expressions or makes frequent errors.
Student can generally rewrite rational expressions in the specified form with minor errors or omissions.
Student accurately rewrites rational expressions in the specified form with only occasional minor errors.
Student consistently and accurately rewrites rational expressions in the specified form, demonstrating a strong understanding of polynomial division and remainders.
Student does not understand that the degree of r(x) must be less than the degree of b(x).
Student demonstrates a limited understanding of the degree relationship, often resulting in incorrect rewrites.
Student sometimes shows an understanding of the degree relationship, but not consistently, leading to some errors.
Student generally understands that the degree of r(x) must be less than the degree of b(x), with occasional oversight.
Student consistently applies the degree relationship correctly when rewriting rational expressions.
Student demonstrates a thorough understanding of the degree relationship and can explain why it must be maintained when rewriting rational expressions.
